p: SARS-CoV-2 is highly contagious with powerful transmissibility. The current evidence suggest that human-human transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is mediated by coughing or sneezing from the infected individual through respiratory droplets (droplet particles >5–10 μm in diameter) in close contact (within 1 m) or as droplet nuclei (particles <5 μm in diameter) which can remain in the air for long periods and be transmitted to others over distances >1 m. The transmission is also possible with the indirect contact with surfaces in the immediate environment exposes to the mucosa by nose and mouth or conjunctiva (eyes) for the viral entry [ 41]. Recent evidence suggest that gastrointestinal symptoms are frequently observed as the viral RNA or live infectious virus present in faeces, which suggests that another possible route might be faecal–oral transmission [ 42]. Interestingly, the possibility of vertical transmission of COVID-19 infection was not observed in two case studies reported so far [ 43, 44].
